title: AE Listing
text: objective tutorial generate production-ready adverse events (AE) listing. AE listing offers comprehensive information desired adverse events. two essential functions constructing AE listing tables metalite.ae: prepare_ae_listing(): prepare AE listing datasets. tlf_ae_listing(): transfer output datasets RTF files. example output:

title: AE Listing
text: Within metalite.ae, utilized ADSL ADAE datasets metalite package create illustrative dataset. metadata structure remains consistent across analysis examples within metalite.ae. Additional information can accessed metalite package website.
code: meta <- meta_ae_example() meta #> ADaM metadata:  #>    .$data_population     Population data with 254 subjects  #>    .$data_observation    Observation data with 1191 records  #>    .$plan    Analysis plan with 18 plans  #>  #>  #>   Analysis population type: #>     name        id  group var       subset                         label #> 1 'apat' 'USUBJID' 'TRTA'     SAFFL == 'Y' 'All Participants as Treated' #>  #>  #>   Analysis observation type: #>     name        id  group var          subset           label #> 1 'wk12' 'USUBJID' 'TRTA'        SAFFL == 'Y' 'Weeks 0 to 12' #> 2 'wk24' 'USUBJID' 'TRTA'     AOCC01FL == 'Y' 'Weeks 0 to 24' #>  #>  #>   Analysis parameter type: #>      name                                label #> 1   'rel'        'drug-related adverse events' #> 2 'aeosi' 'adverse events of special interest' #> 3   'any'                 'any adverse events' #> 4   'ser'             'serious adverse events' #>                                 subset #> 1 AEREL %in% c('POSSIBLE', 'PROBABLE') #> 2                         AEOSI == 'Y' #> 3                                      #> 4                         AESER == 'Y' #>  #>  #>   Analysis function: #>            name                             label #> 1  'ae_summary'    'Table: adverse event summary' #> 2  'ae_listing'          'Listing: adverse event' #> 3  'ae_exp_adj' 'Exposure Adjusted Incident Rate' #> 4 'ae_specific'   'Table: specific adverse event'

title: AE Listing
text: function prepare_ae_listing() used create dataset AE listing utilizing predefined keywords specified example data meta. resulting output function outdata object, comprises collection raw datasets analysis reporting.
code: tbl <- prepare_ae_listing(   meta,   analysis = "ae_listing",   population = "apat",   observation = "wk12",   parameter = "ser" ) head(tbl$tbl) #>          USUBJID ASTDY                                        AEDECOD duration #> 689  01-709-1424     5                                        SYNCOPE    1 Day #> 1131 01-718-1170    27                                        SYNCOPE    2 Day #> 1173 01-718-1371    38 PARTIAL SEIZURES WITH SECONDARY GENERALISATION    4 Day #>         AESEV AESER  related action_taken  outcome      TRTA #> 689  MODERATE     Y Possible         None Resolved High Dose #> 1131   SEVERE     Y Probable         None Resolved  Low Dose #> 1173   SEVERE     Y     None         None Resolved High Dose #>                                                                                  subline #> 689  Subject ID = 01-709-1424, Gender = M, Race = WHITE, AGE = 77 Years, TRT = High Dose #> 1131  Subject ID = 01-718-1170, Gender = F, Race = WHITE, AGE = 80 Years, TRT = Low Dose #> 1173 Subject ID = 01-718-1371, Gender = F, Race = WHITE, AGE = 69 Years, TRT = High Dose head(tbl$col_name) #>                       USUBJID                         ASTDY  #>   "Unique Subject Identifier" "Analysis Start Relative Day"  #>                       AEDECOD                      duration  #>               "Adverse Event"                    "Duration"  #>                         AESEV                         AESER  #>                   "Intensity"                     "Serious"

title: AE Listing
text: last step prepare RTF table using tlf_ae_listing().
code: footnote <- c(   "Related: Investigator-assessed relationship of the adverse event to study medication. Y = RELATED, N = NOT RELATED",   "Action Taken: Discontinued = DRUG WITHDRAWN, Interrupted = DRUG INTERRUPTED, Reduced = DOSE REDUCED, Increased = DOSE INCREASED, None = DOSE NOT CHANGED, N/A = NOT APPLICABLE.",   "Outcome: Resolved = RECOVERED/RESOLVED, Resolving = RECOVERING/RESOLVING, Sequelae = RECOVERED/RESOLVED WITH SEQUELAE, Not resolved = NOT RECOVERED/NOT RESOLVED.",   "Adverse event terms are from MedDRA Version 25.0." ) tbl |> tlf_ae_listing(   footnotes = footnote,   orientation = "portrait",   source = "Source:  [CDISCpilot: adam-adsl; adae]",   path_outtable = "rtf/ae0listing0ser0wk12.rtf",   path_outdata = NULL ) #> The output is saved in/home/runner/work/metalite.ae/metalite.ae/vignettes/rtf/ae0listing0ser0wk12.rtf

title: Subgroup Analysis for Specific AE
text: AE specific subgroup analysis aims provide tables summarize details adverse events subgroup. development AE specific subgroup analysis involves exported functions: prepare_ae_specific_subgroup(): prepare analysis raw datasets. format_ae_specific_subgroup(): prepare analysis (mock) outdata proper format. tlf_ae_specific_subgroup(): transfer (mock) output dataset RTF table.

title: Subgroup Analysis for Specific AE
text: prepare_ae_specific_subgroup() function designed used multiple purposes. input function meta object created metalite package. output function outdata object containing list analysis raw datasets. Key arguments subgroup_var, subgroup_header, display_subgroup_total. output dataset contains commonly used statistics within subgroup_var. variable indexed order outdata$group outdata$subgroup within subgroup_var. row indexed order name within subgroup_var analysis output. n_pop: participants population within subgroup_var. n: number subjects AE within subgroup_var. prop: proportion subjects AE within subgroup_var. diff: risk difference compared reference_group within subgroup_var.
code: meta <- meta_ae_example() outdata <- prepare_ae_specific_subgroup(   meta,   population = "apat",   observation = "wk12",   parameter = "rel",   subgroup_var = "SEX",   subgroup_header = c("TRTA", "SEX"),   display_subgroup_total = TRUE ) outdata #> $components #> [1] "soc" "par" #>  #> $group #> [1] "Placebo"   "Low Dose"  "High Dose" #>  #> $subgroup #> [1] "f" "m" #>  #> title: AE Specification
text: objective tutorial generate production-ready AE specification analyses. extends examples shown specific AE chapter R Clinical Study Reports Submission book. AE specification analysis entails creation tables summarize details different types adverse events. accomplish using metalite.ae, three essential functions required: prepare_ae_specific(): prepare analysis raw datasets. format_ae_specific(): prepare analysis (mock) outdata proper format. tlf_ae_specific(): transfer (mock) output dataset RTF table. three optional functions extend AE specification analysis. extend_ae_specific_inference(): add risk difference inference results based M&N method. extend_ae_specific_duration(): add average duration AE. extend_ae_specific_events(): add average number AE events. example output:

title: AE Specification
text: Within metalite.ae, utilized ADSL ADAE datasets metalite package create illustrative dataset. metadata structure remains consistent across analysis examples within metalite.ae. Additional information can accessed metalite package website.
code: meta <- meta_ae_example() meta #> ADaM metadata:  #>    .$data_population     Population data with 254 subjects  #>    .$data_observation    Observation data with 1191 records  #>    .$plan    Analysis plan with 18 plans  #>  #>  #>   Analysis population type: #>     name        id  group var       subset                         label #> 1 'apat' 'USUBJID' 'TRTA'     SAFFL == 'Y' 'All Participants as Treated' #>  #>  #>   Analysis observation type: #>     name        id  group var          subset           label #> 1 'wk12' 'USUBJID' 'TRTA'        SAFFL == 'Y' 'Weeks 0 to 12' #> 2 'wk24' 'USUBJID' 'TRTA'     AOCC01FL == 'Y' 'Weeks 0 to 24' #>  #>  #>   Analysis parameter type: #>      name                                label #> 1   'rel'        'drug-related adverse events' #> 2 'aeosi' 'adverse events of special interest' #> 3   'any'                 'any adverse events' #> 4   'ser'             'serious adverse events' #>                                 subset #> 1 AEREL %in% c('POSSIBLE', 'PROBABLE') #> 2                         AEOSI == 'Y' #> 3                                      #> 4                         AESER == 'Y' #>  #>  #>   Analysis function: #>            name                             label #> 1  'ae_summary'    'Table: adverse event summary' #> 2  'ae_listing'          'Listing: adverse event' #> 3  'ae_exp_adj' 'Exposure Adjusted Incident Rate' #> 4 'ae_specific'   'Table: specific adverse event'

title: Exposure Adjusted Event Rate
text: \[ \begin{aligned} EAER_j (\text{EAER } Trt_j) &= \frac{\text{total number events } Trt_j}{\text{total person-days } Trt_j/(\text{exp factor})}  \\ &= \frac{\text{total number events } Trt_j \times \text{exp factor}}{\text{total person-days } Trt_j} \end{aligned} \] exposure factor (exp factor) adjusted depending adjustment unit defined users. instance, adjustment unit ‘100 person-month’, EAER computed follows: \[ \begin{aligned} EAER_j (\text{100 person-months}) &= \frac{\text{total number events } Trt_j \times \text{exp factor} (=100\times30.4367)}{\text{total person-days } Trt_j}  \\ &= \frac{\text{total number events } Trt_j \times 3043.67}{\text{total person-days } Trt_j} \end{aligned} \]

title: Unstratified and Stratified Miettinen and Nurminen Test
text: Assume data includes two independent binomial samples binary response variables analyzed/summarized data collected clinical design without stratification. Also approach applicable case data collected using stratified clinical design statistician like ignore stratification pooling data strata assuming two independent binomial samples. Assume \(P_i\) proportion success responses test (\(=1\)) control (\(=0\)) group.

previous_headings: Statistical methods > Unstratified analysis of M&N method
title: Unstratified and Stratified Miettinen and Nurminen Test
text: confidence interval based M&N method given roots \(PD=P_1-P_0\) equation: \[\chi_\alpha^2 = \frac{(\hat{p}_1-\hat{p}_0-PD)^2}{\tilde{V}}\], \(\hat{p}_1\) \(\hat{p}_0\) observed values \(P_1\) \(P_0\), respectively; \(\chi_\alpha^2\) = upper cut point size \(\alpha\) central chi-square distribution 1 degree freedom (\(\chi_\alpha^2 = 3.84\) \(95\)% confidence interval); \(PD\) = difference two population proportions (\(PD=P_1-P_0\)); \[\tilde{V}=\bigg[\frac{\tilde{p}_1(1-\tilde{p}_1)}{n_1}+ \frac{\tilde{p}_0(1-\tilde{p}_0)}{n_0}\bigg]\frac{n_1+n_0}{n_1+n_0-1}\]; \(n_1\) \(n_0\) sample sizes test control group, respectively; \(\tilde{p}_1\) = maximum likelihood estimate proportion test computed \(\tilde{p}_0+PD\); \(\tilde{p}_0\) = maximum likelihood estimate proportion control constraint \(\tilde{p}_1-\tilde{p}_0=PD\). stated 2-sided \(100(1-\alpha)\)% CI given roots \(PD=P_1-P_0\). bisection algorithm used function obtain two roots (confidence interval) \(PD\).

previous_headings: Statistical methods > Unstratified analysis of M&N method
title: Unstratified and Stratified Miettinen and Nurminen Test
text: Z-statistic computed : \[Z_\text{diff}=\frac{\hat{p}_1-\hat{p}_0+S_0}{\sqrt{\tilde{V}}}\] \(\hat{p}_1\) \(\hat{p}_0\) observed values \(P_1\) \(P_0\) respectively, \(S_0\) pre-specified proportion difference null; \(\tilde{p}_1\) = maximum likelihood estimate proportion test computed \(\tilde{p}_0+S_0\); \(\tilde{p}_0\) = maximum likelihood estimate proportion control constraint \(\tilde{p}_1-\tilde{p}_0=S_0\). non-inferiority one-sided equivalence hypothesis \(S_0>0\), p-value, \(\Pr(Z \geq Z_\text{diff} \, | \, H_0)\), computed based \(Z_\text{diff}\) using standard normal distribution. non-inferiority one-sided equivalence hypothesis \(S_0<0\), p-value, \(\Pr(Z \leq Z_\text{diff} \, | \, H_0)\), computed based \(Z_\text{diff}\) using standard normal distribution. two-sided superiority test, p-value \(\Pr(\chi_\text{diff}^2 \leq \chi_1^2 \, | \, H_0)\), computed based \(\chi_\text{diff}^2\) using chi-square distribution 1 degree freedom, \(\chi_\text{diff}^2=Z_\text{diff}^2\).

title: Unstratified and Stratified Miettinen and Nurminen Test
text: Assume data includes two treatment groups, test control, collected based stratified design. Within stratum two independent binomial samples binary response variables analyzed/summarized. parameter interest difference population proportions test control groups. analysis summaries need performed adjusting stratifying variables.

title: Unstratified and Stratified Miettinen and Nurminen Test
text: confidence interval based M&N method given roots \(PD=P_1-P_0\) equation: \[\chi_\alpha^2 = \frac{(\hat{p}_1^*-\hat{p}_0^*-PD)^2}{\sum_{=1}^(W_i/\sum_{k=1}^{K}W_k)^2\tilde{V}_i}\], \(\hat{p}_s^* = \sum_{=1}^(W_i/\sum_{k=1}^KW_k)\hat{p}_{s }\) \(s = 0, 1\); \[\tilde{V}_i=\bigg[\frac{\tilde{p}_{1i}(1-\tilde{p}_{1i})}{n_{1i}}+\frac{\tilde{p}_{0i}(1-\tilde{p}_{0i})}{n_{0i}}\bigg]\frac{n_{1i}+n_{0i}}{n_{1i}+n_{0i}-1}\]; \(W_i\) weight \(\)-th strata; $= K = $ number strata, \(=k=\) strata; \(n_{1i}\) \(n_{0i}\) sample sizes \(\)-th strata test control group, respectively; \(\hat{p}_{1i}\) \(\hat{p}_{0i}\) = observed proportion \(\)-th strata test control, respectively; \(\tilde{p}_{0i}\) \(\tilde{p}_{1i}\) MLE \(P_{0i}\) \(P_{1i}\), respectively, computed constraint \(\tilde{p}_{1i}=\tilde{p}_{0i}+PD\). Similarly unstratified analysis,2-sided \(100(1 - \alpha)\)% CI given roots \(PD = P_1 - P_0\), bisection algorithm used function obtain two roots (confidence interval) \(PD\).

previous_headings: Statistical methods > Stratified analysis of M&N method
title: Unstratified and Stratified Miettinen and Nurminen Test
text: Z-statistic computed : \[Z_\text{diff}=\frac{\hat{p}_1^*-\hat{p}^*_0+S_0}{\sqrt{\sum_{=1}^(W_i/\sum_{k=1}^{K}W_k)^2\tilde{V}_i}}\] \(S_0\) pre-specified proportion difference null; \(\tilde{p}_{0i}\) \(\tilde{p}_{1i}\) MLE \(P_{0i}\) \(P_{1i}\), respectively, computed constraint \(\tilde{p}_{1i} = \tilde{p}_{0i} + S_0\). p-value can calculated stated .

title: Adverse Events Analysis Using metalite
text: metalite.ae R package designed analysis adverse events (AE) clinical trials. operates ADaM datasets adheres metalite structure. R package streamlines process generating production-ready tables, listings, figures outlined AE summary chapter specific AE chapter R Clinical Study Reports Submission book. package encompasses following components:

title: Format AE specific analysis — format_ae_specific
text: outdata outdata object created prepare_ae_specific(). display character vector measurement displayed: n: Number subjects AE. prop: Proportion subjects AE. total: Total columns. diff: Risk difference. diff_ci: 95% confidence interval risk difference using M&N method. diff_p: p-value risk difference using M&N method. dur: Average AE duration. events: Average number AE per subject. digits_prop numeric value number digits proportion value. digits_ci numeric value number digits confidence interval. digits_p numeric value number digits p-value. digits_dur numeric value number digits average duration AE. digits_events numeric value number digits average number AE per subjects. mock boolean value display mock table.

title: Format AE summary analysis — format_ae_summary
text: Format AE summary analysis

title: Format AE summary analysis — format_ae_summary
code: format_ae_summary(   outdata,   display = c("n", "prop", "total"),   digits_prop = 1,   digits_ci = 1,   digits_p = 3,   digits_dur = c(1, 1),   digits_events = c(1, 1),   mock = FALSE )

title: Format AE summary analysis — format_ae_summary
text: outdata outdata object created prepare_ae_specific(). display character vector measurement displayed: n: Number subjects AE. prop: Proportion subjects AE. total: Total columns. diff: Risk difference. diff_ci: 95% confidence interval risk difference using M&N method. diff_p: p-value risk difference using M&N method. dur: Average AE duration. events: Average number AE per subject. digits_prop numeric value number digits proportion value. digits_ci numeric value number digits confidence interval. digits_p numeric value number digits p-value. digits_dur numeric value number digits average duration AE. digits_events numeric value number digits average number AE per subjects. mock boolean value display mock table.

title: Format AE summary analysis — format_ae_summary
text: list analysis raw datasets.

title: Unstratified and stratified  Miettinen and Nurminen test — rate_compare
text: Unstratified stratified  Miettinen Nurminen test. Details can found vignette("rate-compare").

title: Unstratified and stratified  Miettinen and Nurminen test — rate_compare
code: rate_compare(   formula,   strata,   data,   delta = 0,   weight = c("ss", "equal", "cmh"),   test = c("one.sided", "two.sided"),   bisection = 100,   eps = 1e-06,   alpha = 0.05 )

title: Unstratified and stratified  Miettinen and Nurminen test — rate_compare
text: formula symbolic description model fitted, form y ~ x. , y numeric vector values 0 1. x group information. strata optional vector weights used analysis. specified, unstratified MN analysis used. specified, stratified MN analysis conducted. data optional data frame, list, environment containing variables model. found data, variables taken environment (formula), typically environment rate_compare called. delta numeric value set difference two group null. weight Weighting schema used stratified MN method. Default "ss": "equal" equal weighting. "ss" sample size weighting. "cmh" Cochran–Mantel–Haenszel's weights. test character string specifying side p-value, must one "one.sided", "two.sided". bisection number sections interval used bisection method. Default 100. eps level precision. Default 1e-06. alpha Pre-defined alpha level two-sided confidence interval.

title: Unstratified and stratified  Miettinen and Nurminen test — rate_compare
text: data frame test results.

title: Unstratified and stratified  Miettinen and Nurminen test — rate_compare
text: Miettinen, O. Nurminen, M, Comparative Analysis Two Rates. Statistics Medicine, 4(2):213--226, 1985.

title: Unstratified and stratified  Miettinen and Nurminen test — rate_compare
code: # Conduct the stratified MN analysis with sample size weights treatment <- c(rep("pbo", 100), rep("exp", 100)) response <- c(rep(0, 80), rep(1, 20), rep(0, 40), rep(1, 60)) stratum <- c(rep(1:4, 12), 1, 3, 3, 1, rep(1:4, 12), rep(1:4, 25)) rate_compare(   response ~ factor(treatment, levels = c("pbo", "exp")),   strata = stratum,   delta = 0,   weight = "ss",   test = "one.sided",   alpha = 0.05 ) #>         est  z_score            p     lower     upper #> 1 0.3998397 5.712797 5.556727e-09 0.2684383 0.5172779

title:
Unstratified and stratified Miettinen and Nurminen test in
aggregate data level — rate_compare_sum
code: # Conduct the stratified MN analysis with sample size weights treatment <- c(rep("pbo", 100), rep("exp", 100)) response <- c(rep(0, 80), rep(1, 20), rep(0, 40), rep(1, 60)) stratum <- c(rep(1:4, 12), 1, 3, 3, 1, rep(1:4, 12), rep(1:4, 25)) n0 <- sapply(split(treatment[treatment == "pbo"], stratum[treatment == "pbo"]), length) n1 <- sapply(split(treatment[treatment == "exp"], stratum[treatment == "exp"]), length) x0 <- sapply(split(response[treatment == "pbo"], stratum[treatment == "pbo"]), sum) x1 <- sapply(split(response[treatment == "exp"], stratum[treatment == "exp"]), sum) strata <- c("a", "b", "c", "d") rate_compare_sum(   n0, n1, x0, x1,   strata,   delta = 0,   weight = "ss",   test = "one.sided",   alpha = 0.05 ) #>         est  z_score            p     lower     upper #> 1 0.3998397 5.712797 5.556727e-09 0.2684383 0.5172779
